titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Called this morning upon Mr: Van Leyden, but did not find him at home. Wrote some Letters. General Pinckney called on me in the afternoon— Conversation with him. Evening at home.

2. Found Mr: Van Leyden this morning at his new Lodgings. Letter from my brother at Paris. Wrote a long one to Pitcairn— Conversation with General Pinckney. Reading Rousseau’s Nouvelle Héloïse, and the Cardinal de Retz’s Memoires.
3. Mr: Parker called to see me. He is going to Utrecht. Mr: M’Clure from Carolina. Brought me some Letters from America, which Mr: Skipwith sent me, from Paris. Evening, an hour at Mr Veerman’s.

4. Cold, rainy weather. A couple of hours this forenoon with General Pinckney. Dined at Mr: Van Staphorst’s. With the General and his family. Mr: & Madam Schimmelpenninck. Mr: & Madam Veerman, and her brother Loder &c. Evening at home reading.

5. Letter from my brother at Paris which I answered.— Endeavouring to write some observations upon the arreté of the french Executive Directory of 12. Ventose.— Visit this morning from Sir Robert Barclay.— He shewed me a curious Letter from General Eustace.— Called in the Evening at Mr: Veerman’s. Madam was gone to hear the debates of the Assembly.— Called on General Pinckney, and at Messrs: Moliere’s.

6. Breakfasted with General Pinckney, and went with him to visit the cannon foundery. Saw them cast 12 cannon. Mr: Maritz the Director very conversible, and has an high opinion of his talents. All the Sovereigns in Europe would be glad to have him. Evening at Mr: Veerman’s.
7. The preparations are commencing for the Fair. Called on General Pinckney in the afternoon. He is going to Rotterdam to morrow. Evening at home reading.

8. Commencement of the fair— Walked through the Shops. Evening at the french Comedy, where I met Bielfeld. a new Company of performers, rather better than the last. Le Devin du village. La Fausse magie. and Les deux petits Savoyards.

9. Writing my observations all the morning. Met Bielfeld in the afternoon at the Fair. Trumbull’s print of Genl: Washington. Evening again at the french Comedy. L’Ami de la Maison and Nanette et Lucas. The last very indifferent.
10. Dull rainy weather. Finished writing my observations. Evening at Madame de Lange’s, very large company. Whist with Madam Cneiff.— Did not remain to supper.

11. General Pinckney and his family, returned from Rotterdam. He called on me, and had some conversation with me.— Evening again at the French Comedy. Renaud d’Ast, and l’Epreuve villageoise. The last indifferently performed. The other a poor thing itself.

12. Very busily employed the whole day, in writing. Determined upon a point very important to myself. Heaven grant it be for the best.— Evening at the Ball of the Baron de Schubart: dansed a single danse. supped late.— Played whist. My enjoyment for parties of this kind is extinguished for ever.

13. Mr: N. Cutting, Mr: Murray, and Major Rutledge called to see me. Cutting from Paris.— Walk with Mr: Rutledge.— In the afternoon walk with Madam Veerman to Ryswick— Saw the juggling tricks in the Evening at the fair.
14. Still contrive to make myself busy doing nothing.— Walk in the wood.— At the fair, which is to be prolonged three days of the coming week. Evening at Madam Cneiff’s with a small company.

15. Sale of books at Bool’s which I attended. Went in the afternoon with General Pinckney, his Lady and daughter to Zorgvliet; the Seat and Gardens on the Scheveling road, belonging to Count Bentinck. Found them in better condition than was to be expected.— After returning, I went to see the glass blower at the fair. The performance is curious.— The canary birds were dull. In the forenoon, I saw the monstrous dwarf, who is between 60 and 70 years of age, and about 30 inches high. His Head would be remarkably large for a man of 6 feet. The sight is more strange than pleasing.

16. Attended again the sale of books. Letters from my brother at Paris, which I answered. He begins to think of his return.— Weather very fine; walk in the afternoon with Madame Veerman, to Eckenduyn. the catholic burying ground, and ruins of a Convent, which I have seen heretofore Returned by the walk round the downs, and through the wood.

17. At the sale of books. At the fair. At General Pinckneys. This is the closing day for the fair.— Completing the list of books. Few of them still left to pack up. Walk in the wood alone, towards Evening.— Reading Rousseau’s Emile. It deserves attention.

18. Dined at Count Löwenhielm’s. Small party. Walk in the wood after dinner and met Major Rutledge. Called at Madam May’s. The Count took Bielfeld & myself with him. Tea party at M: & Madame Noël’s. Company very large and brilliant. Reversi with Madam Noël, Madam de Lange and Count Löwenhielm.

19. Bad night. Suffer for want of exercise. Packed off a couple of boxes of books to the President of Harvard University, for the library. Walk with Madam Veerman in the afternoon, over the Downs, to Scheveling.

20. Pass’d the day, as usual in writing and making my Preparations. At the sale in the morning. Evening at the french play. Met there, Major Rutledge and Mr: Horry. Le faux Lord, an indifferent opera, though the music be of Piccini, and Les deux petits Savoyards.

21. Mr: Erving called on me this morning: agreed to go with him and Mr: Teery, to Mr: Beeldemaker’s seat at Ryswick. By the mistake of our Coachman, we arrived late.— Genl: Pinckney and his family. Several other American Gentlemen. Company large. Mr: Beeldemaker has a family of 9 very fine children. His wife appears to be very amiable.— We returned between 8 and 9. The remainder of the Evening at Madam Cneiff’s.

22. Called this morning on Mrs: Pinckney. Attended her, and the General; and Mr: Horry, to the Assembly. Found Madam Schimmelpenninck, and Mlle: Nahuys there.— Walk afternoon. Evening at Madam Schimmelpenninck’s.— Madam Cneiff there, and company accordingly.

23. Walk this forenoon in the wood. Met Messieurs Levsen, and Ricordain.— Ball at Count Löwenhielm’s. Party numerous and agreeable. In honour of M. & Madame Noël. 4 Tables at supper, in three apartments. Was requested to do the honours, that is to sit at the head of one of the tables, with Madam Bosset.— Played at Reversi, before supper.— Came home at about 2 in the morning, leaving most of the company there.— Went to Bed by day-light, and slept not till long after sun-rise.
24. Late up, as to be expected.— Walk in the afternoon with Madam Veerman; weather fine. Found my books this evening on my return home.
25. Packing up my books the whole forenoon. Dined at Mr: Noël’s: very large company. Very gay.— Evening at Madam May’s. Walk alone in the wood, at the close of the Evening. Weather extremely warm.

26. Did not close my eyes, the whole Night. Weary and restless; rose before 6, and walked alone to Loosduynen. Weather very warm. A thunder shower in the forenoon cooled it. Passed an hour or two at the Assembly. Dined at Mr: Schimmelpenninck’s. Genl: Pinckney and his family. Madam Veerman.— Mlle: Nahuys left us just after dinner, and is going to Haerlem. Upon returning to my lodgings, found my brother had returned from Paris. Met him soon after in the Street. conversation with him untill late in the night.

27. Went with my brother this forenoon, and presented him to General Pinckney.— Called early in the afternoon on Madam Veerman. Walk with her. Went out on the Ryswick road through the Oost Indisch weg; came out near the House in the wood: from thence went round the grounds of Mr: Fagel, and returned by the road from Scheveling. Long and pleasant tour.

28. Major Rutledge called upon me this morning. And Bielfeld; with whom I took a walk in the wood: and in the afternoon to Scheveling. Called at the Baron de Schubart’s, upon our return; but they were not at home.

29. Examining the papers left by the late Mr: Dumas.— Walk in the afternoon, with Madam Veerman. We were caught in the rain. Arrived therefore late at Mr: Bosset’s.— Play’d Reversi. Conversation with Madam de Schubart at supper.

30. Intended to have gone this day to Amsterdam. But find myself so much engaged that I could not get away. Busy through the day, in sorting papers. Called towards Evening upon General Pinckney.— Received a packet from London, containing Letters from my mother.

31. Employed all the forenoon in writing. At 1/2 after 4. Took the boat for Leyden, and arrived there just before eight. Found Mr: Schermerhorn at the Golden Lion.— Called to see Mr: Luzac, and had some conversation with him.— Ball at the house where I lodged— Noisy night.
Day.— Nothing regular— A situation which must not long continue.
